title: Trust Wallet Chrome extension hack causes $7M in crypto losses
executive_summary: The Trust Wallet Chrome browser extension (version 2.68) was compromised, leading to unauthorized draining of user funds totaling approximately $7 million in various cryptocurrencies. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
Trust Wallet confirmed the incident and urged affected users to update immediately to version 2.69, confirming reimbursement for losses. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
what_happened: A malicious version (2.68) of the Trust Wallet Chrome browser extension was published — potentially via compromised Web Store credentials — injecting hidden JavaScript that exfiltrated sensitive wallet data. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

Users who imported seed phrases or interacted with the compromised extension had their wallets drained as attackers captured credentials and moved funds to external addresses. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
Reports indicated losses of roughly $6–7 million across Bitcoin, Ethereum, BNB, Solana, and other chains. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
Trust Wallet released a patched version (2.69) and instructed users to stop using the vulnerable version immediately. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
who_is_affected: Users of the Trust Wallet Chrome extension version 2.68. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Self-custody holders who imported seed phrases into the compromised extension. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
Crypto users active during the holiday period (Christmas Eve/Day 2025). :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
attack_flow: Compromised extension update (v2.68) released via Chrome Web Store. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
Hidden malicious code runs on install or use, capturing seed phrases. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
Captured credentials allow the attacker to access wallets and transfer funds. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}
Funds are drained and moved to external wallets on multiple chains. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}
business_impact: Loss of user funds totaling ~ $6–7 million. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}
Reputational damage and erosion of trust in browser extension wallets. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}
Emergency patch release and user support overhead. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}
risk_reason: Browser extension supply-chain attacks exploit trust in Web Store updates and can capture sensitive input like seed phrases, enabling full wallet compromise. :contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}
what_usually_goes_wrong: Automatic updates introduce malicious code without verification. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}
Users import seed phrases into compromised software. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}
Insufficient vetting or protection of extension publishing credentials. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}

immediate: Disable the affected Trust Wallet Chrome extension version 2.68. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}
Update immediately to the official fixed version 2.69. :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}
short_term: Review transaction history and secure remaining funds in offline wallets. :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}
Avoid entering seed phrases into browser extensions. :contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}
long_term: Audit and restrict browser extension use in high-risk environments. :contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}
Implement multi-factor safeguards for wallet access beyond seed phrases. :contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}

what_this_does_not_mean: All Trust Wallet products are insecure — only a specific extension version was affected. :contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}
The core blockchain protocols were hacked. (This was an extension compromise.)

signs: Unexpected outflows from wallets without user authorization. :contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}
alerts: Warnings from on-chain monitoring tools about rapid fund movement. :contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}
